unit_designation: 1st Free French Brigade (1ère Brigade Française Libre)

commander.name: Général de Division Marie-Pierre Kœnig
commander.previous_service: Hero of Bir Hakeim defense (26 May - 11 June 1942)
commander.note: Free French forces under British operational command

tanks.note: 22nd North-African French Armored Company - mix of Crusader and light tanks

artillery.note: Reorganized with British equipment after Bir Hakeim - four batteries of 4x 88mm guns

soft_skin_vehicles.note: British lend-lease vehicles for brigade mobility

armored_cars.note: Infantry brigade - no organic reconnaissance vehicles

notes: Integrated into British 8th Army supply system
Higher fuel reserves due to extended desert operations experience

weather_environment.terrain_type: Desert - Southern El Alamein sector near Qattara Depression
notes: Extreme desert heat - peak summer temperatures
Southern sector near Qattara Depression - more challenging terrain
Sandstorms minimal but heat exhaustion major concern

subordinate_units.note: French Polynesia, New Caledonia, New Hebrides volunteers
French naval infantry with attached British 43rd Battery, 11th City of London Yeomanry
French Foreign Legion - fought at Bir Hakeim and El Alamein
Reorganized with British equipment after Bir Hakeim losses
Engineers, signals, medical, transport, headquarters staff

tactical_doctrine.role: Independent infantry brigade for defensive operations, integrated into British XIII Corps at El Alamein southern sector
special_capabilities: Exceptional morale - fighting for Free France and liberation
Desert warfare experience from Bir Hakeim defense (15-day stand against Rommel)
Multi-national composition (French, African, Pacific, Spanish Republican volunteers)
known_issues: Mix of outdated French and new British equipment
Rebuilding after heavy Bir Hakeim casualties (lost 900 men)

historical_context.operational_status: Active - Reorganizing after Bir Hakeim, preparing for Second Battle of El Alamein
major_battles: Battle of Bir Hakeim (26 May - 11 June 1942): Heroic 15-day defense, 99 killed, 109 wounded, 763 missing. Delayed Rommel's offensive and allowed British forces to retreat to El Alamein
Second Battle of El Alamein (23 October - 11 November 1942): 1st BFL participated in breakthrough operations
notes: Formed from Free French colonial forces after France's 1940 surrender
Under British operational command, retained French national identity
Bir Hakeim defense (26 May - 11 June 1942) became symbol of Free French resistance
General Kœnig refused Rommel's surrender demands: 'Nous ne nous rendrons pas' (We will not surrender)
Brigade became core of 1st Free French Division (formed February 1, 1943)
Composed of volunteers from French colonies (Africa, Pacific), Foreign Legion, and Spanish Republicans
